litstudy.common¶

class litstudy.common.Affiliation(**kwargs)¶

The affiliation of the Author of a Document.

city = None¶

The city where the institution is, or None if unavailable.

country = None¶

The country where the institution is, or None if unavailable.

name = None¶

The name of the institution.

class litstudy.common.Author(**kwargs)¶

Author of Document.

affiliations = None¶

Affiliations of the author as list of Affiliation objects, or None if unavailable.

name = None¶

Name and surname of the author.

orcid = None¶

The ORCID of the author, or None if unavailable.

class litstudy.common.Document(**kwargs)¶

Meta data of academic document.

abstract = None¶

Abstract of document, or None if unavailable.

authors = None¶

Authors of document as list of Author objects, or None if unavailable.

citation_count = None¶

The number of received citations, or None if unavailable.

id = None¶

The platform transparent DocumentID.

keywords = None¶

List of author specified keywords, or None if unavailable.

language = None¶

Language of the document, or None if unavailable.

publisher = None¶

The name of the publisher, or None if unavailable.

references = None¶

List of titles of referenced papers.

source = None¶

Name of source (for example: ‘The International Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining’) or None if unavailable.

source_type = None¶

Type of source (for example: ‘Conference Proceedings’) or None if unavailable.

title = None¶

Title of document.

year = None¶

Year of publication as integer.

class litstudy.common.DocumentID(doc_id=None)¶

The platform transparent ID of a Document.

parse_bibtex(bibtex_entry)¶

Retrieve the ID of a document from a BibTex entry.

parse_dblp(dblp_result)¶

Retrieve the ID of a document from the DBLP entry.

parse_scopus(scopus_abstract)¶

Retrieve the ID of a document from a Scopus abstract.

class litstudy.common.DocumentSet(docs)¶

Set of documents from retrieved from search query.

docs = None¶

List of documents as Document objects.

filter(predicate)¶

Returns a new DocumentSet object which includes only documents for which the given predicates returns true.

Parameters

predicate – The predicate to check.

Returns

A DocumentSet instance

filter_duplicates(key=None)¶

Remove duplicate documents from this DocumentSet.

Parameters

key – lambda which takes a document and returns a unique key.

This key is used as an identifier to check if two documents are identical. By default, equivalence is determined based on DOI (if available) or title (if available). :return: A DocumentSet instance

union(other, key=None)¶

Returns the union of this DocumentSet and another DocumentSet and remove duplicate entries. By default, equivalence is checked using the same method as filter_duplicates.

litstudy.plot¶

litstudy.plot.generate_topic_cloud(model, topicid, cmap=None, max_font_size=75, background_color='white')¶

Generate the word cloud for the word distributions of a single topic from a topic model.

Parameters

  • model – The TopicModel.

  • topicid – The topic index within the topic model.

  • cmap – The color map to use for the foreground colors, defaults to “Blues”.

  • background_color – The background color, defaults to “white”.

  • max_font_size – The maximum font size.

  • **kwargs – Additional parameters passed to wordcloud.WordCloud.

Returns

A wordcloud.WordCloud instance.

litstudy.plot.plot_affiliation_histogram(docset, top_k=10, ax=None, filename='translations_affiliations.yml', clean=True)¶

Plot a histogram of the number of documents published by each affiliation. Note that this is done on a best-effort basis since one affiliation could have multiple spellings (e.g., “University of Amsterdam”, “Universiteit van Amsterdam”, or “UvA”). The user is presented with the option to merge potential duplicate affiliation names.

Parameters

  • docset – The DocumentSet.

  • ax – The axis on which to plot the histogram, defaults to current axis.

  • top_k – Limit results to the top k institutes.

  • filename – Filename to read from/write to (previous) affiliation name cleaning decisions.

  • clean – Switch off the cleaning process.

litstudy.plot.plot_affiliation_type_histogram(docset, x=10, ax=None)¶

Plot a histogram of the number of documents published by each type of affiliation (e.g., research institutes, academic institute, company, etc.)

Parameters

  • docset – The DocumentSet.

  • ax – The axis on which to plot the histogram, defaults to current axis.

  • top_k – Limit results to the top k entries.

litstudy.plot.plot_author_affiliation_histogram(docset, top_k=30, ax=None)¶

Plot a histogram of the number of documents published by each combination of author + affiliation. This helps to reduce the name number of collisions for different persons having the same name.

Parameters

  • docset – The DocumentSet.

  • ax – The axis on which to plot the histogram, defaults to current axis.

  • top_k – Limit results to the top k combinations.

litstudy.plot.plot_author_histogram(docset, top_k=20, ax=None)¶

Plot a histogram of the number of documents published by each author. Note that this is done on a best-effort basis since one author could have published under multiple spellings of the same name (e.g., “Alan Turing”, “A. Turing”, or “A. M. Turing”)

Parameters

  • docset – The DocumentSet.

  • ax – The axis on which to plot the histogram, defaults to current axis.

  • top_k – Limit results to the top k authors.

litstudy.plot.plot_bigram_histogram(freqs, dic, top_k=25, ax=None)¶

Plot a histogram of bigram frequency in the documents.

Parameters

  • docset – The DocumentSet.

  • ax – The axis on which to plot the histogram, defaults to current axis.

  • top_k – Limit results to the top k entries.

litstudy.plot.plot_country_histogram(docset, top_k=10, ax=None)¶

Plot a histogram of the number of documents published by each country based on author affiliation. Note that the country is not always available.

Parameters

  • docset – The DocumentSet.

  • ax – The axis on which to plot the histogram, defaults to current axis.

  • top_k – Limit results to the top k country.

litstudy.plot.plot_language_histogram(docset, ax=None)¶

Plot a histogram of the number of documents published for each language (e.g., English, German, Chinese, etc.)

Parameters

  • docset – The DocumentSet.

  • ax – The axis on which to plot the histogram, defaults to current axis.

litstudy.plot.plot_number_authors_histogram(docset, ax=None)¶

Plot a histogram of the number of authors per document.

Parameters

  • docset – The DocumentSet.

  • ax – The axis on which to plot the histogram, defaults to current axis.

litstudy.plot.plot_source_histogram(docset, top_k=10, ax=None, filename='translations_sources.yml', clean=True)¶

Plot a histogram of the document source. Note that this done on a best-effort basis since one publication venue could have multiple spellings.

Parameters

  • docset – The DocumentSet.

  • ax – The axis on which to plot the histogram, defaults to current axis.

  • top_k – Limit results to the top k sources.

  • filename – Filename to read from/write to (previous) source cleaning decisions.

  • clean – Switch off the cleaning process.

litstudy.plot.plot_source_type_histogram(docset, ax=None)¶

Plot a histogram of the document source types (e.g., Journal, conference proceedings, etc.)

Parameters

  • docset – The DocumentSet.

  • ax – The axis on which to plot the histogram, defaults to current axis.

litstudy.plot.plot_statistic(fun, docset, x=None, ax=None, x_label='', count=None, vertical=False, title=None)¶

Plot statistics of some sort in a bar plot. If x is not given, (None) all keys with a count > 0 are plotted. If x is a list, the counts of all list elements are included. If x is an integer, the x keys with highest counts are plotted.

litstudy.plot.plot_topic_cloud(model, topicid, ax=None, **kwargs)¶

Plot the word distributions of a single topic from a topic model.

Parameters

  • model – The TopicModel.

  • topicid – The topic index within the topic model.

  • ax – The axis on which to plot the histogram, defaults to current axis.

  • **kwargs – Additional parameters passed to generate_topic_cloud.

litstudy.plot.plot_topic_clouds(model, cols=3, fig=None, **kwargs)¶

Plot the word distributions of a topic model.

Parameters

  • model – The TopicModel.

  • cols – Number of columns (e.g., word clouds per row).

  • fig – The figure on which to plot the results, defaults to current figure.

  • **kwargs – Additional parameters passed to plot_topic_cloud.

litstudy.plot.plot_topic_map(model, dic, freqs, ax=None, seed=0)¶

Embeds the documents onto a 2D plane.

litstudy.plot.plot_words_histogram(freqs, dic, top_k=25, ax=None)¶

Plot a histogram of word frequencies in the documents.

Parameters

  • docset – The DocumentSet.

  • ax – The axis on which to plot the histogram, defaults to current axis.

  • top_k – Limit results to the top k entries.

litstudy.plot.plot_year_histogram(docset, ax=None)¶

Plot a histogram of the number of documents published for each year.

Parameters

  • docset – The DocumentSet.

  • ax – The axis on which to plot the histogram, defaults to current axis.

litstudy.nlp¶

litstudy.network¶

litstudy.network.plot_citation_network(docs, **kwargs)¶

Plot the citation network of the given DocumentSet where nodes represent document and edges represents citations between documents.

Parameters

  • docs – The DocumentSet

  • **kwargs – Additional arguments passed to networkx.draw

litstudy.network.plot_coauthor_network(docs, top_k=25, min_degree=1, **kwargs)¶

Plot the citation network of the given DocumentSet where nodes represent author and edges represents collaborations (e.g. number of shared documents between two authors.)

Parameters

  • docs – The DocumentSet

  • min_degree – Only show nodes of at least this degree, defaults to 1

  • top_k – Only show labels for the top k nodes.

  • **kwargs – Additional arguments passed to networkx.draw
